Automakers estimate it would take months to reestablish supply chains, with current inventory expected to last only weeks, suggesting a potential crisis extending into early 2026.

keyTakeAways: Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, is central to the US-China trade dispute due to its critical role in supplying automotive chips, especially transistors and diodes.

The dispute began when the US Commerce Department restricted Wingtech Technologies (China-based parent company of Nexperia) in December 2024, escalating with China banning Nexperia China’s exports in October 2025.
The Dutch government took control of Nexperia following China’s export ban, indicating a geopolitical shift in ownership and control of the company.
Nexperia produces about 40% of automotive chips in the transistor and diode segment, making it a vital supplier to global auto manufacturing.
Automakers are alarmed by the potential for plant shutdowns, with supply chains expected to last only weeks and recovery taking months.
The crisis could drive up car prices, as seen during the 2020–2021 chip shortage, with average US new car prices now exceeding $50,000.
Automaker groups like the Alliance for Automotive Innovation and the European Automobile Manufacturers Association are urging immediate diplomatic and trade solutions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, is at the center of a growing US-China trade dispute initiated by U.S. restrictions on its Chinese parent company, Wingtech Technologies, in December 2024. This was followed by China banning Nexperia China’s exports in October 2025, prompting the Dutch government to take control of the company. Given that Nexperia produces about 40% of automotive transistors and diodes, a critical component in modern vehicles, the disruption threatens global auto production. Automakers from the U.S. and Europe warn of potential plant shutdowns, with supply chains expected to last only weeks and recovery taking months. The crisis could drive up car prices, as seen during the 2020–2021 chip shortage, with average new car prices in the U.S. now surpassing $50,000. Industry leaders and trade groups are urging swift diplomatic action to resolve the dispute and prevent economic and industrial fallout.
title: US-China trade dispute over a little-known Dutch chipmaker could halt car production and send prices higher
